Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Supervision
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12207
Section (3) An agency shall require that social service workers be directly
Description responsible for all of the following:
(a)Placing and supervising children in out-of-home care. Social
service workers shall work directly with the children, their families,
and other relevant individuals and be primarily responsible for the
development, implementation, and review of service plans for
children and their families.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation On 3/28/2024 Youth A presented to the hospital with mental
health concerns and was to receive inpatient psychiatric
treatment. On 3/29/2024 Youth A was reevaluated and was ready
for discharge and the agency administration did not make
arrangement with the hospital for the youth’s discharge, despite
the hospital's repeated attempts to contact the agency to arrange
discharge, causing the hospital to believe the youth had been
abandoned.
Investigation Interviews:
On 4/3/2024, I interviewed Youth A’s Michigan Department of
Health and Human Services-Purchase of Services (MDHHS-
POS) Worker 2 by telephone. MDHHS-POS Worker 2 reported
the hospital left her a message, an email and contacted her
supervisor on Friday (3/29/2024). MDHHS-POS Worker 2 did not
get the telephone message or email until Monday (4/1/2024). The
Hospital Social Worker (HSW) also called her on 4/1/2024. The
HSW reported Youth A needed to be picked up from the hospital,
and if not, the hospital would call children protective services
(CPS). The HSW admitted the hospital had previously indicated
they were going to admit Youth A, but on Friday, the hospital
assessed Youth A could do a partial stay and Youth A would
come to the hospital for outpatient treatment.
MDHHS-POS Worker 2 reported the hospital reported they could
not get in touch with a supervisor/ administrative staff at Spectrum
related to Youth A’s discharge. MDHHS-POS Worker 2 reported
Spectrum had workers on shift at the hospital with Youth A. She
said she spoke with a worker (she didn’t say who) while the staff
were onsite and this person tried to call their supervisor without
success (no answer). MDHHS-POS Worker 2 said she knew the
2

Case Manager was out. She did not understand why no other
administrative staff was reachable.
On 4/5/2024 I interviewed the Case Manager about this allegation
face-to-face at the agency’s administrative office in collaboration
with MDHHS Worker 1 (MDHHS Worker 3 was also present
observing the interview). Case Manager said she was out of
town on leave from 3/29/2024- 4/2/2024. She said on 3/29/2024
she had received a phone call from Hospital Worker 1 (she could
only recall his first name) about discharge planning for Youth A.
She called Hospital Worker 1 back and spoke with them on
3/29/2024 around 6:40pm. Hospital Worker 1 wanted the Case
Manager to call Hospital Worker 2 (whose name the Case
Manager could not recall). The Case Manager phoned Hospital
Worker 2 that same day and Hospital Worker 2 told her to call
Hospital Worker 1. The Case Manager reported since she had
already spoken to Hospital Worker 1 on 3/29/2024 and had
advised Hospital Worker 1 to contact the Case Manager’s
supervisor, she did not make another call to Hospital Worker 1.
The Case Manager said she did not provide her supervisor’s
name or number as she assumed the hospital had the Chief
Administrator’s (CA) and other agency staff contact information on
file. She said, if the hospital had emailed her, (which she
discovered they had on 3/29/2024) her out of office notification
would deploy and give instruction as to whom to contact in her
absence, that being the CA.
The Case Manager reported there is not a 24-hour contact
number and that the hospital had her work telephone number and
the CA’s work number. The Case Manager said on 3/29/2024 she
also reached out to the CA by text; and advised the CA the
hospital had contacted her about Youth A on 3/29/2024. She did
not recall whether she told the CA the call was about Youth A
being discharged. She said when she spoke with the hospital
workers, she thought they wanted to know if Youth A could come
back to Spectrum’s IL home; but she now understands it was
about Youth A being released from the hospital.
The Case Manager reported Spectrum has staff to supervise a
youth when a youth is at or admitted to a hospital. This happened
with Youth A’ past hospital stays. To her knowledge staff were at
the hospital during Youth A’s entire stay. When asked whether
staff were told what to do about a youth’s discharge, the Case
Manager reported that staff would know this would be coordinated
by other supervisory staff.
3

On 4/2/2024 I spoke with the Chief Administrator (CA) about this
allegation by telephone. I interviewed the CA face-to-face at the
agency’s administrative office on 4/5/2024 in collaboration with
MDHHS Worker 1 (MDHHS Worker 3 was also present observing
the interview). The CA reported being surprised about the
complaint. She said youth workers had been at the hospital
monitoring Youth A since Youth A went to the hospital on
3/28/2024 related to the last incident of Youth A taking edibles.
She said the hospital had initially indicated they were admitting
Youth A; and prior to this Spectrum was connecting with MDHHS
about Spectrum’s Independent Living (IL) placement not being
appropriate for Youth A. The CA reported she had advised
MDHHS, Spectrum could not accommodate Youth A for 30 days.
Spectrum was awaiting a TDM (Team Decision Meeting) that was
set for 4/3/2024; at which time they could have Youth A with
another placement.
The CA admitted the Case Manager contacted her on 3/29/2024
reporting the hospital contacted the Case Manager. The CA
reported there were no other conservations with the Case
Manager. The CA did not say whether or not she knew that the
contact was about Youth A’s discharge. Nor did she report
Spectrum was not open to Youth A being discharged back to
Spectrum. Her response was she contacted Spectrum’s
Residential Supervisor and advised that supervisor the CA
needed to talk with MDHHS about the CA’s concerns with Youth
A’s continued placement with Spectrum prior to accepting the
discharge. The CA acknowledged receipt of an email from the
hospital about Youth A’s readiness for discharge on 4/1/2024. She
said she advised the hospital that the agency needed to talk with
MDHHS. She asked the hospital for more time related to Youth
A’s discharge. The hospital asked what her timeframe was, but
she was not aware of the hospital’s question until the next day.
She reported she was trying to work Youth A’s placement situation
out with MDHHS. She said she spoke with the MDHHS
Supervisor on 4/1/2024 between 5:00-6:00pm; and that supervisor
indicated the MDHHS Supervisor would need to speak with her
direct supervisor about the matter. The MDHHS Supervisor
advised the CA afterwards that per the MDHHS Supervisor’s
contact with their supervisor, Spectrum must submit a 30-day
removal request to have Youth A’s placement moved. The CA
reported on 4/1/2024 she informed her administrator of MDHHS’s
decision about Youth A and she made it clear to the hospital they
were taking Youth A back. The CA did not clarify how she had
made that clear. She said on 4/2/2024 she called the staff to tell
them to advise the hospital Spectrum was able to complete the
4

discharge. On 4/2/2024 she and the Residential Supervisor also
saw the email from the hospital that was mentioned prior, and she
replied to it. The CA said she also spoke with a female hospital
social worker on 4/2/2024 and she advised this person Spectrum
would be taking Youth A back.
The CA reported Spectrum staff is/were aware they could not
bring Youth A from the hospital prior to an approval from their
supervisor or her. She denied the agency abandoning Youth A at
the hospital.
The CA did not perceive the agency’s delayed actions pertaining
to Youth A ‘s discharge as not appropriate. Nor that there may
have been some confusion by the hospital as to what the agency
would be doing related to Youth A. The CA accepted the
indication it could be seen that way; because when a youth is
ready for discharge, arrangement for such is to happen swiftly.
She thought she had made it clear to the hospital on 4/1/2024
they were taking Youth A back, though she did not clarify how she
had done that.
On 4/3/2024 I interviewed the Hospital Social Worker (HSW) by
telephone. The HSW reported on 3/29/2024 at approximately
4:00pm, the hospital told Spectrum staff onsite that Youth A was
ready for discharge. The staff attempted to reach the Case
Manager more than once without success. The HSW reported at
approximately 10:00pm the Case Manager called the hospital and
reported the Case Manager would contact the Guidance Center to
authorize mental health care for Youth A. Additionally, the Case
Manager was going to speak with her supervisor, but the Case
Manager, nor another Spectrum supervisor, or administrator
called the hospital back that day. The HSW reported over the
weekend their department continued their efforts to facilitate Youth
A’s discharge. He said his co-worker left messages for the Case
Manager on Saturday and Sunday. The HSW did not report
having an on-call number for the agency. The hospital’s contact to
the Case Manager was by cell phone and email. They had also
spoke with a prior provider of Youth A, in hopes of facilitating a
plan for Youth A.
The HSW reported after failed attempts to execute Youth A’s
discharge over the weekend, on Monday morning he sent an
email to MDHHS staff and the Spectrum CA asking about a
timeline for Youth A’s discharge. Spectrum did not respond, and
later that afternoon the HSW sent another email to MDHHS, the
Case Manager, and CA asking if Youth A had been abandoned.
5

The HSW said the CA responded around 2:40pm with a vague
response, “something about being in discussions with MDHHS”.
On Tuesday after 2:00pm the CA responded indicating they would
make arrangements for Youth A’s discharge.
The HSW reported Spectrum never said they would not or could
not take Youth A back. He also confirmed Spectrum had staff
onsite at the hospital supervising Youth A all weekend. But those
staff reported they could not connect with a supervisor related to
Youth A’s discharge plan. The HSW reported he learned via Youth
Worker (YW)1 they/staff onsite at the hospital had information
about what was going on, but they were not to update the hospital.
The HSW said per YW 1 and the last email from the CA, he
surmised the agency was having discussions about whether
Youth A would or would not be returning to the agency’s program,
but they were not telling the hospital this information.
On 4/22/2024, I interviewed Youth Worker (YW) 1 by telephone.
She reported she and other staff were supervising Youth A the
entire time Youth A was in the hospital. She worked the morning
shifts 7:00am- 3:00pm and sometime 4:00pm. YW 1 said she
could not speak to the other staff’s location during their time at the
hospital, but she was always in Youth A’s room during her entire
shift. She reported not being able to speak to whether staff could
reach a supervisor related to Youth A’s discharge, but reported
the Residential Supervisor also completed some shifts. She
reported the administration makes the decisions about youth’s
discharge planning.
On 3/28/2024 I interviewed Youth A at the hospital related to
special investigation 2024SIC000274, and just prior to receipt of
this complaint. At that time the Hospital Psychiatrist reported
Youth A would be admitted. A staff person was supervising Youth
A at this time. I attempted contact with Youth A after her
discharge from the hospital, return to Spectrum independent living
home, but thereafter she was sent to Havenwyck and contact was
not able to occur.
Document Review:
• Youth A’s MISACWIS case record which showed she is a
permanent court ward, who has had numerous placements,
inclusive of a number of past residential placements.
• A copy of a 3/23/2024, 3/24/2024, and 3/25/2024 unusual
incident report related to Youth A’s hospital visits due to
self-harming/suicidal ideations, and the Hospital Visit
Summaries related to those visits.
6

• A copy of the email chain from the hospital to MDHHS,
which included the Case Manager and the CA at different
times as recipients. These emails showed:
✓ On 4/1/2024(8:16am) the HSW contacted
MDHHS-POS Worker 2, the MDHHS Supervisor,
another MDHHS Staff and the Case Manager
advising that Youth A was ready for discharge
from the emergency department, and asking when
Youth A would be picked up.
✓ On 4/1/2024(12:57pm) the MDHHS Supervisor
emailed the HSW, (with a copy to the other
recipients on the HSW first email), asking whether
Youth A had been picked up. The HSW replied to
all (which now included the CA) Youth A was still
at the hospital.
✓ A 4/1/2024(2:22pm) reply from the MDHHS
Supervisor asking for the CA’s assistance with the
discharge plan, since the Case Manager is out.
✓ On 4/1/2024 (3:11pm) The HSW seeking a time for
Youth A’s pick up after being advised by the CA
the agency is in discussion with MDHHS about
Youth A’s placement and what’s in her best
interest, and will respond back as soon as
possible; thereon the HSW asked about the time
frame for the discussion, no reply back that day
from the CA.
✓ A 4/1/2024 (3:42pm) from the Hospital
Psychiatrist to the HSW (with a copy to the other
prior recipients) advising all that soon there will be
pressure from physicians related to Youth A’s
discharge and for the department/Spectrum to
remedy the situation. Thereafter, another email by
the HSW indicating a concern Youth A has been
abandoned.
✓ A 4/1/2024(7:18am) email from the HSW advising
as the Youth A has been ready for discharge since
3/29/2024 and the hospital had to make a referral
around the child likely being abandoned by the
agency. Then a response by the CA (at 8:07am)
that Youth A has not been abandoned, the agency
staff has been at the hospital the entire time.
Additionally, it has been in discussion with MDHHS
as previously mentioned; and at this point since
there is no other placement available for Youth A,
Youth A will be returning to the independent living
placement with Spectrum; Spectrum will follow the
7

safety plan and discharge plan provided by the
hospital.
Analysis The agency is not in compliance with the rule:
It is established by way of individuals interviewed that the agency
provided staff supervision of Youth A while she was at the
hospital. It is also established that the hospital indicated Youth A
was ready for discharge to her placement on 3/29/2024; and after
she wasn’t discharged, the hospital sought MDHHS assistance
and pressed the need for Youth A’s release from the hospital to
the agency’s Case Manager and CA via email on 4/1/2024. The
agency did not have clear communication with the hospital about
Youth A’s discharge and did not arrange for her discharge to her
placement until 4/2/2024.
The agency did not work promptly with the hospital related to
Youth A’s discharge, return to placement and allowed Youth A to
remain at the hospital in a limbo state from 3/29/2024 until
4/2/2024.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Continuation of the facility’s current licensing status is recommended.
